dt: {bc}to destroy the self-possession or self-confidence of (someone) {bc}{sx|disconcert||}

dt.t: He had never blushed in his life; no humiliation could {wi}abash{/wi} him.

utxt.t: … I turned to Susan, still sitting there huddled up in her coat, looking, to my {wi}abashment{/wi}, as helpless as the day I had found her.

pt: {sc}embarrass{/sc} {sc}discomfit{/sc} {sc}abash{/sc} {sc}disconcert{/sc} {sc}rattle{/sc} mean to distress by confusing or confounding. {sc}embarrass{/sc} implies some influence that impedes thought, speech, or action.

pt.t: the question {it}embarrassed{/it} her so much she couldn't answer

pt: {sc}discomfit{/sc} implies a hampering or frustrating accompanied by confusion.
{sc}abash{/sc} presupposes some initial self-confidence that receives a sudden check, producing shyness, shame, or a feeling of inferiority.

pt.t: {it}abashed{/it} by her swift and cutting retort

pt: {sc}disconcert{/sc} implies an upsetting of equanimity or assurance producing uncertainty or hesitancy.

pt.t: {it}disconcerted{/it} by finding so many in attendance

pt: {sc}rattle{/sc} implies an agitation that impairs thought and judgment.

et: Middle English {it}abaissen, abaschen{/it} "to lose one's composure," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}abaiss-{/it}, stem of {it}abair{/it} "to open wide, gape, be amazed," alteration (by prefix substitution) of {it}esbaer{/it} (Continental Old French {it}esbahir{/it}), from {it}es-{/it} "out" (going back to Latin {it}ex-{/it}) + {it}baer{/it} "to open wide, gape," going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*batāre{/it} {ma}{mat|ex-:1|}, {mat|abeyance|}{/ma}
shortdef: to destroy the self-possession or self-confidence of (someone) : disconcert
